newsitem.title: USA: Most U.S. spot resid prices again lose ground.
newsitem.headline: Most U.S. spot resid prices again lose ground.

text.p: U.S. spot fuel oil prices again mostly lost ground Monday in lackluster activity, still pressured by weak crude, mild weather forecasts and relatively cheap gas prices, industry sources said.

"Crude is weak, gas is cheap and the weather has been warm. There's still a lot of bearish sentiment in the market," said one cash trader, noting many East Coast utilities recently made the switch to cheaper natural gas.
New York Harbor physical one percent tumbled 50 cents to $15.00-25 a barrel, with March paper sold early at $14.85, then quoted later at $14.75, off 40 cents, traders said.
NYH April one percent paper also was quoted at $14.65-80, down more than 50 cents on the day.
High sulphurs in New York also lost ground, with 2.2 slipping a quarter to $13.50-75, traders said.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour again held steady in the low-$17s, but traders said still-cheap city gate gas prices continued to siphon utility demand.
U.S. Gulf one percent skidded more than a quarter to $14.25, with one trader reportedly offering prompt barrels as low as $14 (FOB Houston). USG three percent was down slightly to $11.75-12.00.

New York city gate swing gas prices firmed slightly to $2.15/mmBtu, or about $13.55 a barrel equivalent. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, again held steady at about $1.80/mmBtu, or $11.34 a barrel equivalent.
